config.question: Why did an independent black antislavery movement emerge in the 1830s?

choices.content: Blacks disliked the radical methods adopted by whites.
There were tensions between blacks and whites over leadership positions.
The white abolitionist movement had failed.
Whites had a general lack of empathy of blacks.

answer_3.response: Consider This: A black antislavery movement emerged after 1830 that was largely independent of the white-led crusade. In addition to Frederick Douglass, prominent black male abolitionists were Charles Remond, William Wells Brown, Robert Purvis, and Henry Highland Garnet. See L.O. 12.3 What were the major antebellum reform movements?
